unless otherwise noted, all figures in this emodule are from gray’s anatomy for students, 3e, by drake , vogl, & mitchell, © 2015 by elsevier. this is a recommended resource. click to continue click to continue click to continue emodule tutorial emodule tutorial emodule tutorial

previous next using the emodule use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool. to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of the pages, swipe next, or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking “menu” at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages, swipe previous or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. lab 2 prelab slm 2a exercise 2.1 exercise 2.2…

unit 1 overview previous next in unit 1, students are introduced to the body wall, its contents and innervation. unit 1 is comprised of 3 six-hour laboratory periods that are either split up over 2 half days, or occur over the course of one full day. during each of the three labs students will complete 4 separate exercises. within a given lab room, students are divided into four lab groups of 8 - 9 students. these are designated lab groups a-d. the students within each of these groups will dissect, learn from, and share the care of two cadavers, one male and one female, for the duration of the academic year. each lab group (a-d) is divided into lab pairs 1-4 and each pair starts the lab on the exercise that corresponds to their pair number. pairs will have approximately 90 minutes to complete the tasks associated with a given exercise before the ta announces that it is time to rotate to the next exercise. students are not permitted to move from one station to the next until instructed to do so by the ta. if the station involves dissection, the first pair will start the dissection. after 90 minutes, the next pair will continue dissecting where the last pair left off. in most cases, the dissection will not be completed until the fourth group contributes, which means earlier pairs must circle back to see the completed work. if you are done all of the tasks at a station and completed the end-of-exercise quiz in quizlandia before it is time to rotate, click on the “field trip” button. this provides you with a list of specimens to look at in grant’s museum of anatomy, ms1150, to enhance your understanding of the material presented in the lab. all students must prepare for each lab session by completing the prelab slm(s). each lab session begins with an app-based lab rat on the prelab slm(s). in the case of a full-day lab, students will complete two rats, one at the start of the morning session, and another at the start of the afternoon session. it is imperative that students also preview the lab exercises that they will complete during the session in order to derive the most benefit out of the practical laboratory experience.

the film button appears on the bottom bar of slides where a video accompanies tasks or explanations. the photo button appears at the bottom of slides where a photo accompanies tasks. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to jump to related content. click the icon to jump back. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should become familiar. previous got it, let’s move on conventions used in the emodule with age, wear and tear, info information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below the bar: and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. note how they fit together, tas k tasks, introduced on a pink bar and continued below the bar in bold, are actions that you should take to help you understand the content: an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus…. the slide talk icon appears on the top bar of slides containing a recording of me explaining concepts.

lab 2 instructions previous next the six hours dedicated to lab 2 take place over the course of one full day during week 4. prior to lab 2, you will complete exercise 2a, a short self-learning module (slm) that teaches you some basics regarding the nerves and lymphatics of the thorax. this is to be completed before the lab. both the morning and afternoon lab 2 sessions will begin with an app-based quiz on this slm. during lab you will complete exercises 2.1 - 2.4, in which you will study the bony thorax, thoracic wall, lungs and diaphragm, and the mediastinum. the material for these exercises will be placed at four different stations around your lab room. preview this content prior to lab. you will work and rotate with your pairs: if, before it is time to rotate, you have completed i) all of the tasks in a given exercise, ii) your progress checks, and iii) completed the end of exercise quiz in quizlandia, click on the “field trip” button. this will provide you with a list of specimens to look at in grant’s museum of anatomy, ms1150, to enhance your understanding of the material presented in the lab. exercise stg 9:00-10:30mam 10:00-11:30 stg 10:30-12:00 mam 11:30 - 1:00 stg 12:00-1:00 mam 1:00-1:30 stg 1:00-2:30mam 2:00-3:30 stg 2:30-4:00 mam 3:30 - 5:00 2.1 pairs 1 pairs 4 lunch pairs 3 pairs 2 2.2 pairs 2 pairs 1 lunch pairs 4 pairs 3 2.3 pairs 3 pairs 2 lunch pairs 1 pairs 4 2.4 pairs 4 pairs 3 lunch pairs 2 pairs 1

2a nerves and lymphatics of the thorax next objectives when you have learned the material presented in this module, you will be able to: describe the innervation of the thoracic wall. describe the innervation of thoracic viscera. describe the lymphatic drainage of the body wall. exercise selection
next previous innervation of the thoracic wall and thoracic viscera 2 2a part 1

next previous 2a the innervation of “the container” in the first anatomy lab, you learned about the innervation of target tissues in the body wall and limbs by spinal nerves and their branches. recall that targets in the body wall and limbs are threefold: skeletal muscle, innervated by somatic motor neurons, sensory receptors in skin, muscle and joints vascular smooth muscle, arrector pili muscle and glands, innervated by sympathetic postganglionic neurons. in this slm, you will: review this aspect of the nervous system (i.e. the innervation of the “container”) as it applies to the specific case of the thoracic wall and also be introduced to the innervation of thoracic viscera (i.e. the innervation of the “contents”) by the autonomic nervous system, the ans. 3

next previous 2a introduction to the ans the autonomic nervous system innervates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands. most targets of the autonomic nervous system receive innervation from both the sympathetic and parasympathetic subdivisions of the autonomic nervous system. you discovered a major exception to this in lab 1, when you learned that smooth muscle and glands in the limbs and body wall are controlled exclusively by the sympathetic nervous system. there is no parasympathetic innervation of the body wall or limbs. 4

from superficial to deep, the layers of the thoracic wall are: the skin (composed of the epidermis and dermis) the hypodermis or superficial fascia (loose ct and adipose) deep fascia (not shown; consists of a thin layer of dense irregular ct) ribs, their associated skeletal muscles, major nerves, and blood & lymphatic vessels parietal pleura, a serous membrane that covers, and is adhered to, the inner thoracic wall. next previous 2a innervation of the thoracic wall the thoracic body wall is innervated by branches of the thoracic spinal nerves, t1-t12. branches of the dorsal and ventral rami of the thoracic spinal nerves, containing somatic motor fibres, sensory fibres and sympathetic postganglionic fibres, ramify to innervate their target tissues in all of these layers. 5

the dorsal rami of thoracic spinal nerves, you will recall, extend posteriorly to innervate the para -axial region, including the intrinsic back muscles and overlying skin. next previous 2a intercostal nerves 6 the ventral rami of the t1-t11 spinal nerves continue between adjacent ribs as the intercostal nerves. the ventral ramus of the t12 spinal nerve continues inferior to the twelfth rib as the subcostal nerve . as they sweep anteriorly and inferiorly across the chest wall, the t7 - t11 intercostal nerves and the subcostal nerve cross the costal margin to enter the abdominal wall and contribute to its innervation, as well.

next previous 2a the sympathetic chain in the thorax 7 recall that spinal nerves and their branches, the dorsal and ventral rami, contain sensory, somatic motor and sympathetic postganglionic fibres. intercostal nerves, being the continuation of ventral rami, contain this same complement of fibre types. the sympathetic postganglionic fibres innervate vascular smooth muscle, arrector pili muscle and glands. the cell bodies of these sympathetic postganglionic fibres are located in the sympathetic chain ganglia. the connections between the spinal nerves and sympathetic chain are the rami communicantes.

next previous 2a the rami communicantes and the thoracic wall the white ramus communicans (myelinated) conveys sympathetic preganglionic fibres arising from cell bodies in the t1 - l2 levels of the spinal cord to a sympathetic chain ganglion (solid line). the grey ramus communicans (unmyelinated) conveys sympathetic postganglionic fibres from the ganglion back to the ventral and dorsal rami, to be distributed via their branches, including the intercostal and subcostal nerves, to smooth muscle and glands in the body wall and limbs (dotted line). 8

next previous 2a autonomic innervation of thoracic viscera the content so far has applied what you know about the innervation of the body wall and limbs to the specific case of the thoracic wall. next you will be introduced to the innervation of thoracic viscera. thoracic viscera receive both sympathetic and parasympathetic input. for any given thoracic organ, the two arms of the autonomic nervous system oppose each other. for instance, the sympathetic nervous system increases heart rate, while the parasympathetic nervous system decreases heart rate. 9

next previous 2a sympathetic innervation of thoracic viscera sympathetic outflow to all body targets arises from the spinal cord between segments t1 and l2; i.e. the cell bodies of sympathetic preganglionic neurons are restricted to these levels of the spinal cord . sympathetic output for thoracic viscera is further restricted to the t1-t4 (or t5) spinal levels, varying between individuals. preganglionic sympathetic axons leave the spinal cord via the ventral root and spinal nerve, and travel via a white ramus communicans to a sympathetic ganglion. rather than traveling back to the spinal nerves via a grey ramus communicans, as occurs with the innervation of the body wall and limbs, the postganglionic axons destined to innervate thoracic viscera form sympathetic visceral nerves, often called splanchnic nerves. the example illustrated is of the sympathetic cardiac nerves, also known as the cardiac splanchnic nerves. there are also esophageal and pulmonary splanchnic nerves. 10 for thoracic viscera, the cell bodies of postganglionic neurons are located in the sympathetic chain ganglia; these ganglia, therefore, contain the cell bodies of sympathetic postganglionic neurons destined to innervate both the body wall / limbs and thoracic viscera . this is illustrated on your spinal cord model here: .

next previous 2a parasympathetic innervation of thoracic viscera parasympathetic output for most body targets arises from the brainstem and travels with certain cranial nerves. these targets are in the face, thorax, and the proximal abdomen. parasympathetic output for targets in the distal abdomen, pelvis and perineum arises from sacral levels s2-s4 of the spinal cord, in the form of the pelvic splanchnic nerves . note that, like the sympathetics, parasympathetic innervation of viscera involves a two-neuron chain, with the cell body of the preganglionic neuron in the cns and the cell body of the postganglionic neuron in a ganglion in the pns. for targets in the face, parasympathetic ganglia are associated with cranial nerves and are called terminal ganglia . for targets elsewhere, the ganglia are called intramural ganglia . thoracic viscera receive parasympathetic preganglionic input from cranial nerve x, the vagus nerve. parasympathetic ganglia are located within the walls of the heart, esophagus and airways. 11

next previous 2a visceral plexuses in lab 1 you learned about somatic plexuses, in which the ventral rami derived from different spinal nerves overlap, combining their fibres to form compound peripheral nerves containing axons from multiple spinal levels fibres from different origins combine, similarly, in autonomic or visceral plexuses, where parasympathetic fibres combine with sympathetic fibres as they approach their target organs. 12

next previous 2a visceral plexuses contain motor fibres 13 examples of autonomic plexuses in the thorax includes the cardiac, pulmonary and esophageal plexuses, in which vagal preganglionic parasympathetic fibres mingle with sympathetic postganglionic fibres carried in splanchnic nerves arising from the upper sympathetic chain ganglia.

next previous 2a visceral plexuses contain sensory fibres 14 viscera are innervated by sensory fibres, as well as sympathetic and parasympathetic motor fibres. thus, visceral nerves contain both sensory and motor fibres. some sensory fibres travel with the parasympathetics, back along the vagus nerve to their origin in the brainstem. these sensory fibres carry homeostatic information, such as blood gas and blood pressure. other sensory fibres travel with the sympathetics, back along the cardiac, esophageal or pulmonary splanchnic nerves, back to their origin in the upper thoracic spinal cord levels. these sensory fibres carry information regarding tissue damage due to inflammation, ischemia and undue stretch, which the cns interprets as pain.

next previous 2a visceral pain refers to the body wall 15 neurological basis of referred pain is illustrated here. as stated on the previous slide, information regarding ischemic damage to the heart is carried by sensory fibres back to the spinal cord within the cardiac splanchnic nerves, mixed with the sympathetic motor fibres that originate in the t1 - t4 spinal levels. in addition to sensory input from the heart, the t1 - t4 levels also receive sensory feedback regarding tissue damage from their dermatomes, which are the inner arm and upper chest wall. notice in the diagram that the information from the heart and chest wall converge onto the same sensory neuron in the spinal cord. these neurons cannot distinguish the origin of the input, and convey the information regarding tissue damage to the brain, where it is interpreted coming from the chest wall. thus, persons experiencing angina pectoris describe it as crushing “chest pain”, that often extends along the medial aspect of the arm. note that visceral sensory neurons travel back to the spinal cord along the same route taken by sympathetic motor fibres; through the cardiac splanchnic nerves, white ramus and dorsal root . cardiac pain refers to the inner arm and chest wall. info visceral pain is said to “refer” to the body wall because pain due to irritation of a viscus is perceived, by the individual experiencing it, to come, not from the affected organ, but from the body wall. the
next previous an introduction to lymphatics 16 2a part 2

next previous 2a lymph is excess interstitial fluid lymphatic capillaries open into lymph nodes, which act as in-line filters, cleansing lymph of antigen, such as pathogens and transformed (cancerous) cells that have metastasized from primary tumors. because lymph percolates slowly through lymph nodes, transformed cells can grow as secondary tumors in lymph nodes, and pathogens can cause changes in lymph nodes that cause them to enlarge and become tender. palpation of lymph nodes is an important clinical skill. 17 interstitial fluid is formed by the extravasation of plasma across the walls of capillaries into the interstitial space , where it bathes our cells and tissues. oxygen and nutrients, carbon dioxide and metabolites, diffuse through interstitial fluid between blood and cells. while most interstitial fluid returns to venous blood in the periphery, a fraction enters lymphatic capillaries to become lymph; some cells, cell products and pathogens may also enter lymphatic capillaries. cleansed lymph is returned to venous blood. thus lymph is derived from blood via interstitial fluid, and returned to blood.

next previous 2a lymph nodes lymph forms throughout the body in the peripheral tissues, with the exception of the brain, bone marrow, and avascular tissues, such as epithelia and cartilage. all lymph passes through at least one lymph node, often many, before it is returned to venous blood. lymph nodes are abundant where lymph collects from body surfaces, external and internal, as these are sites of pathogenic invasion. skin covers our external body surface; intact skin is a barrier to pathogenic invasion. broken or compromised skin is an access 18 point for pathogens. lymph from these surfaces collect in superficial nodes. internal surfaces include those associated with our digestive and respiratory tracts, for instance, across which pathogens present in food and air may enter the body. lymph from these surfaces collects in deep nodes, such as those associated with the aorta and trachea, respectively. lymph nodes are clustered in junctional regions of the body, such as the neck, axilla and inguinal region. in these locations, lymph nodes can limit the spread of antigen and disease from one body region to another. the physician has access to cervical, axial and inguinal lymph nodes for palpation, unlike deep nodes, such as those associated with the aorta and trachea.

next previous 2a larger lymph vessels 19 lymphatic capillaries coalesce repeatedly, forming progressively larger lymphatic vessels called lymphatic trunks that ultimately converge to form the largest lymphatic vessels in the body, the lymphatic ducts. lymphatic ducts empty into the great veins in the neck. the thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body. as illustrated by the darker shaded area in accompanying diagram, it collects lymph bilaterally from tissues below the diaphragm , and conducts it superiorly. in the posterior thorax, the thoracic duct collects lymph bilaterally from the thoracic wall. in the neck, near its terminus, the thoracic duct accepts lymph from the left side of the head and neck via the left jugular trunk, from the left upper limb via the left subclavian trunk, and from the left thoracic viscera via the left bronchomediastinal trunk. from the thoracic duct, lymph from these three quadrants of the body drains into venous blood at the left venous angle, which is the convergence of the left internal jugular vein with the left subclavian vein .

next previous 2a lymph from the upper right quadrant 20 lymph drainage from the upper right quadrant of the body is illustrated by the lighter shaded area in the accompanying diagram. lymph from the right side of the head and neck drains via the right jugular trunk, lymph from the right upper limb and axilla drains via the right subclavian trunk, and lymph from the right thoracic contents drains via the right bronchomediastinal trunk. these converge on the right venous angle, often forming the right lymphatic duct before emptying into the right venous angle.
next previous 2a quiz skip 21 press or swipe next to start the quiz or skip to end exercise 2a.

congratulations on finishing slm 2a nerves and lymphatics of the thorax! previous back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review slm 2a review slm 2a review slm 2a
2.1 the bony thorax resources hanging skeleton loose ribs thoracic vertebrae next what you’ll need: exercise selection

2.1 objectives next previous identify the features of true, false and floating ribs, and their attachments to the vertebral column and sternum. identify the features of the sternum and describe the clinical significance of the sternal angle (angle of louis). enumerate the ribs and intercostal spaces. identify the superior and inferior thoracic apertures and the structures that pass through them. 2

next previous 2.1 layers of the thoracic wall from superficial to deep, the layers of the thoracic wall are: the skin (composed of the epidermis and dermis) the hypodermis or superficial fascia (consisting of loose connective tissue and a variable amount of adipose) deep fascia (not shown; consisting of a thin layer of dense irregular connective tissue) ribs and their associated skeletal muscles, major nerves and blood & lymphatic vessels parietal pleura, a membrane that covers, and is adhered to, the inner thoracic wall. 3

next previous 2.1 the pleural space pleural spacea pleural space separates the inner surface of the thoracic wall from the outer surface of the lung. the pleural space is a potential space containing only a capillary layer of pleural fluid. visceral pleuravisceral pleura covers, and is adhered to the outer surface of the: lung 4

next previous 2.1 a typical rib pick up a rib from amongst those with which you have been provided. identify the head, tas k crest, neck, tubercle, angle and costal groove. identify the two articular facets, tas k separated by the crest on the head of the rib, and a third facet on the tubercle of the rib. the costal groove runs along the inferior border of the rib on its internal surface. with that, you now know “up from down” and can correctly orient the rib in your hand. it is at these facets that ribs articulate with the vertebral column. now that you know “up from down” and which end articulates with the vertebral column, you can determine whether the rib in your hand is from the right or left side of the body. 5

next previous 2.1 costovertebral articulations articulate the following structures: tas k pick up two thoracic vertebrae and articulate them with each other. now articulate the rib you’ve been studying with the vertebrae in your hand. notice that the crest on the head of the rib articulates with the site where the intervertebral disc would be located. the tubercular facet of the rib articulates with the costal facet of the transverse process of the numerically corresponding vertebra; i.e. the tubercular facet of the sixth rib articulates with the costal facet on the transverse process of the sixth rib. 6

next previous 2.1 the bony thorax i turn your attention to the bony thorax of the hanging skeleton in your lab. identify and note the relationships: tas k the bony thorax consists of the twelve thoracic vertebrae, twelve pairs of ribs and the sternum. along their length, ribs are largely bone, but end anteriorly with a tip of hyaline cartilage, the costal cartilage. count the ribs tas k from superior to inferior. 7

next previous 2.1 the bony thorax ii identify the true ribs, tas k false ribs, and floating ribs, using the following descriptions as a guide: all ribs articulate posteriorly with the vertebral column. however, anteriorly, “true ribs” articulate directly with the sternum via their costal cartilage; which are the true ribs? “false ribs” do not articulate directly with the sternum; which are the “false ribs”? observe that ribs 8-10 tas k articulate anteriorly with the costal cartilage of the rib above, and thus articulate indirectly with the sternum. 8

next previous 2.1 the bony thorax iii identify the costal margin tas k on the hanging skeleton and on yourself by palpation. “floating ribs” are false ribs that have no anterior articulation; their cartilaginous tips end in the musculature of the thoracic body wall. which are the “floating ribs”? the costal margin , is the inferomedial border of the ribcage, formed by the connected cartilages of ribs 7 – 10 and the xiphoid process. 9

next previous 2.1 clinical significance: cervical ribs a supernumerary rib, info called a “cervical rib”, is present in 1% of the population. cervical ribs articulate with the seventh cervical vertebra, and may be present unilaterally or bilaterally. a cervical rib may result in thoracic outlet syndrome (see below). 10

next previous 2.1 the sternum turn your attention to the sternum of the hanging skeleton in your lab. identify the three elements tas k that form the sternum: from superior to inferior, these are the manubrium , the body of the sternum and the xiphoid process. identify the jugular or suprasternal notch tas k of the manubrium, both on the hanging skeleton, and on yourself at the base of your neck in the midline. what pair of ribs articulates with the manubrium? notice that the clavicles also articulate with the manubrium. palpate tas k the medial (sternal) end of your own clavicles. explain why you cannot palpate the articulation between the pair of ribs identified above and the manubrium. 11

next previous 2.1 the angle of louis identify on the skeleton tas k the manubriosternal joint or sternal angle. clinicians often refer to the sternal angle by the eponym , “the angle of louis”. the sternal angle info is an important clinical landmark; it is the reference point from which you will measure the height of the jugular venous pressure (jvp) during physical examination. what pair of ribs articulates with the sternum at the sternal angle? palpate your own sternal angle: tas k it is located roughly three fingers’ breadth (~4-5 cm) inferior to your jugular notch. 12

next previous 2.1 enumerating ribs slide your fingers laterally, tas k along the sternal angle, and palpate the costal cartilages of the ribs identified above, which articulate with the sternum at the sternal angle. look at the skeleton tas k and confirm that the remaining true ribs articulate with the body of the sternum. to count ribs, start with the ribs that articulate at the sternal angle, sliding your fingers inferiorly along the lateral edge of the sternum, and then inferolaterally adjacent to the costal margin. attempt this on yourself, or on a willing, preferably underfed, male colleague. 13

next previous 2.1 the intercostal spaces i the spaces between the ribs are called the intercostal spaces. the first intercostal space lies between the first rib and the second rib. thus, intercostal spaces are enumerated relative to the rib above. what intercostal space lies between ribs 7 and 8? identify on the skeleton tas k the left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line. by the end of this lab you should be able to explain why this landmark is important. 14

next previous 2.1 the intercostal spaces ii in life, the intercostal spaces are closed by muscles of respiration that extend from rib to rib, and contain the arteries, veins, lymphatics and nerves that supply the thickness of the thoracic wall. 15

next previous 2.1 the thoracic outlet identify on the skeleton tas k the superior thoracic aperture , also known as the “thoracic outlet”, and the structures that form its borders: the first thoracic vertebra the first ribs the superior border of the manubrium if viscera are to pass between the thorax and either the head & neck, or the upper limbs, they must pass through this opening. the thoracic outlet, being composed of bone, is rigid. it contains viscera, such as the trachea, esophagus, the apices of the right and left lungs, great vessels (common carotid and subclavian arteries, internal jugular and subclavian veins), lymphatics draining the head, neck and upper limbs, and major nerves. 16

next previous 2.1 clinical significance: thoracic outlet syndrome if any one of these structures become enlarged, info it will compress the others, due to the rigidity of the thoracic outlet, resulting in the signs and symptoms of “thoracic outlet syndrome”. this might occur, for instance, in the case of a tumor in the apex of a lung. as the tumor enlarges, adjacent viscera will become compressed, and their function compromised. if the great vessels are compressed, pulses in the affected upper limb might be weakened and venous return might be compromised. the resultant vascular signs and symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome include a pale, swollen, cold, and / or aching upper limb. neurological signs of thoracic outlet syndrome include weakness and wasting of muscles of the hand and numbness, pain or tingling in the upper limb. thoracic outlet syndrome can also occur in a patient with a cervical rib (see above), which can compress structures entering or exiting the thoracic outlet. 17

next previous 2.1 the inferior thoracic aperture and the diaphragm identify on the skeleton tas k the inferior thoracic aperture and the structures that define it: these are the twelfth thoracic vertebra, the 12th and 11th ribs, the costal margin and the ziphisternal joint. the inferior thoracic aperture is the origin of the thoracic diaphragm, a muscular sheet that almost completely closes this opening. structures that pass between the thorax and the abdomen pass either behind the diaphragm (e.g. the aorta) or through openings in the diaphragm (e.g. the esophagus and inferior vena cava). 18

next previous 2.1 progress check 19 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: from superficial to deep, what are the layers of the thoracic wall? identify the features of a typical rib: head with its articular facets, crest, neck, tubercle, transverse facet, angle, costal groove. given a typical rib, use its features to orient it properly and identify it as a right or left rib; articulate it properly with a pair of thoracic vertebrae. identify correctly the ribs and intercostal spaces of a bony thorax; identify the true ribs, false ribs and floating ribs; identify the costal margin. what is a cervical rib? how common are cervical ribs? at what vertebral level do they most commonly occur? identify the manubrium, body and xiphoid process of the sternum; identify the suprasternal notch and sternal angle. which pair of ribs articulate at the manubrium? which pair of ribs articulate at the sternal angle? what structures form the borders of the thoracic outlet (superior thoracic aperture)? what structures form the borders of the inferior thoracic aperture? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next exercise.
next previous 2.1 quiz press or swipe next to start the quiz or skip to end exercise 2.1. skip 20

congratulations on finishing exercise 2.1 the bony thorax! next exercise next exercise next exercise back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review exercise 2.1 review exercise 2.1 review exercise 2.1 previous
2.2 the thoracic wall resources prosection of posterior and superior mediastinum chest plates from cadavers 1 & 2 next what you’ll need: exercise selection

2.2 objectives next previous describe the innervation of the thoracic wall. identify the structures within the posterior and superior mediastinum. describe and identify the blood supply to and from the thoracic wall. 2

next previous 2.2 unwrap the prosection unwrap the prosection tas k of the posterior and superior mediastinum. you must never use dissecting tools on a prosection; use blunt tools only for pointing as you study and discuss the prosection with your peers. you must moisten all prosections every 30 minutes as long as they are unwrapped. 3

next previous identify on the prosection: tas k the aorta, trachea & primary bronchi and esophagus. identify the aortic arch and its three main branches, the brachiocephalic trunk, the left common carotid artery and the left subclavian artery. identify the two branches tas k of the brachiocephalic trunk, the right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery. the subclavian arteries and their branches supply the shoulders and upper limbs. the common carotid arteries and their branches supply the head and neck. 2.2 the posterior and superior mediastinum tas k esophagus (e) left common carotid artery (lcc) left subclavian artery (lsa) arch of the aorta (aa) left main bronchus (lmb) thoracic aorta (ta) diaphragm (d) esophagus (e) right main bronchus (rmb) brachiocephalic trunk (bt) trachea (t) 4

next previous 2.2 the right and left venous angles identify on the prosection: tas k the formation of the r. brachiocephalic v. by the union of the r. subclavian v. and the r internal jugular v. identify on the prosection: tas k the formation of the l. brachiocephalic v. by the union of the l. subclavian v. and the l internal jugular v. identify on the prosection: tas k the formation of the superior vena cava (svc) by the union of the r. and l. brachiocephalic veins. the svc returns venous blood to the r. atrium of the heart. note that in the prosection, the left brachiocephalic v. may have been transected, as indicated by the two dotted lines in the figure, in order to expose the branches of the arch of the aorta. 5 this is the right venous angle. this is the left venous angle.

next previous identify on the prosection: tas k the ribs and intercostal spaces in the posterior body wall and note the muscles joining adjacent ribs; these are the intercostal muscles. the intercostal muscles function to move the ribs so as to change the volume of the thorax during inspiration and expiration. from superficial to deep, there are three layers of intercostal muscles: the external, internal and innermost intercostal muscles. identify the posterior intercostal tas k vein and artery and the intercostal nerve lateral to the vertebral column; in each intercostal space, they are in this order (van: vein, artery, nerve), from superior to inferior. 2.2 the intercostal space i posterior ramus of spinal nerve lateral branch of intercostal nerve and vessels anterior intercostal artery and vein intercostal nerve collateral branch of intercostal nerve and vessels anterior perforating branches of intercostal vessels anterior cutaneous branch of intercostal nerve internal thoracic artery and vein aorta serratus anterior muscle external intercostal muscle internal intercostal muscle innermost intercostal muscle skin superficial fascia lung pleural cavity visceral pleura parietal pleura intercostal vein intercostal artery intercostal nerve collateral branches endothoracic fascia costal groove 6

next previous 2.2 the intercostal space ii note how these structures tas k disappear behind the innermost intercostal muscles as they pass anteriorly around the thoracic body wall. the intercostal neurovascular bundles are located between the internal and innermost intercostal muscles. the components of the intercostal neurovascular bundle give branches that supply tissues throughout the thickness of the thoracic wall, from the skin to the parietal pleura. serratus anterior muscle external intercostal muscle innermost intercostal muscle skin superficial fascia lung pleural cavity parietal pleura intercostal vein intercostal artery collateral branches endothoracic fascia internal intercostal muscle visceral pleura intercostal nerve 7

next previous 2.2 the intercostal nerves i trace the intercostal nerves tas k back toward the vertebral column and notice that they disappear into the intervertebral foramina between adjacent vertebrae. remember, intercostal nerves are continuations of ventral rami; they unite with dorsal rami to form spinal nerves in the intervertebral foramina. the intercostal nerves contain: somatic motor axons which innervate skeletal muscle, sensory axons which monitor receptors throughout the thickness of the thoracic wall, from the skin to the parietal pleura sympathetic postganglionic fibres that innervate vascular smooth muscle throughout the thickness of the body wall, and the arrector pili muscle and glands of the skin. spinal cord posterior ramus posterior branch lateral cutaneous branch anterior branch small collateral branch lateral branch medial branch anterior cutaneous branch intercostal nerve 8

next previous 2.2 the sympathetic chain intercostal nerves also contain sympathetic postganglionic fibres which innervate vascular smooth muscle, arrector pili muscle and glands. the cell bodies of these sympathetic postganglionic fibres are located in the sympathetic chain ganglia. identify the sympathetic chain tas k and find connections between the ventral ramus / intercostal nerve and the sympathetic chain. these connections are called the rami communicantes. the rami communicantes are very delicate; be careful not to damage them. sympathetic ganglion (sg) sympathetic trunk (st) grey and white rami communicantes (g&w) intercostal nerve (in) greater splanchnic nerve (gsn) lesser splanchnic nerve (lsn) least splanchnic nerve (ltsn) 9

next previous 2.2 the posterior intercostal arteries trace the posterior intercostal arteries tas k back to their origin from the thoracic aorta. parietal branches of the thoracic aorta are the posterior intercostal arteries; they supply the thickness of the chest wall. visceral branches of the thoracic aorta supply the esophagus, bronchial tree and the coverings of the heart, the pericardium. these are the esophageal, bronchial and pericardial arteries. 10

next previous 2.2 the posterior intercostal veins posterior intercostal veins drain the posterior thoracic body wall back to the right side of the heart via the azygous venous system. on the right side of the specimen, tas k trace the posterior intercostal veins back to the azygous vein and trace the azygous vein superiorly; note that it arches over the right primary bronchus. the azygous vein drains into the superior vena cava, which returns blood to the right atrium of the heart. on the left side of the specimen, tas k trace the posterior intercostal veins back to the hemiazygous and accessory hemiazygous veins. find the connection between these veins and the azygous vein. venous blood from the left side of the thoracic body wall drains across the midline into the azygous vein, and from there flows superiorly into the superior vena cava. left internal jugular vein left brachiocephalic vein intercostal vein accessory hemiazygous vein hemiazygous vein inferior vena cava azygous vein right atrium superior vena cava 11

next previous 2.2 proper care of the prosection carefully moisten and wrap the prosection of the posterior and superior mediastinum. don’t put it away in its bag yet, as you will look at it again. you must, however, protect it from drying out in the meantime. 12

next previous 2.2 progress check 1 13 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the aorta, aortic arch, brachiocephalic trunk and its branches, the right subclavian and right common carotid arteries, the left common carotid artery, left subclavian artery. what, in general is the distribution of the subclavian arteries? of the common carotid arteries? identify the right and left venous angles and the veins that unite at each; identify the right and left brachiocephalic veins and the superior vena cava. name, from superficial to deep, the intercostal muscles. what is their function? identify a posterior intercostal vein and artery, and an intercostal nerve. between which two layers of intercostal muscles are the intercostal neurovascular bundles located? how does this help you to identify the intercostal muscles? name the three fibre types present in an intercostal nerve and the targets of each in the thoracic body wall. identify the sympathetic chain, and, if possible, identify its connections to the spinal nerve / ventral ramus via rami communicantes. what is meant by the terms, “parietal” and “visceral” branches of the aorta? name the parietal and visceral branches of the thoracic aorta. identify the posterior intercostal veins, the azygous, hemiazygous and accessory hemiazygous veins. identify the union of the azygous vein with the superior vena cava. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

next previous 2.2 the internal thoracic and anterior intercostal arteries turn your attention to the chest plates taken from your two cadavers. on the internal surface of the chest plate, tas k on either side of the sternum, find vessels running vertically along its lateral borders. these are the internal thoracic (internal mammary) artery and vein(s). you may clean them with dissecting tools to make them clearer. find a branch tas k of one or more of these vessels and follow it into an intercostal space, dissecting if necessary. these are anterior intercostal arteries and veins. the internal thoracic arteries arise bilaterally from the right and left subclavian arteries. the anterior intercostal arteries form arterial anastomoses with the posterior intercostal arteries in the thoracic wall, roughly along the midclavicular line. aorta internal thoracic artery anterior perforating branches anterior intercostal a. superior epigastric a. musculophrenic a. collateral branch of posterior intercostal a. posterior intercostal a. subclavian a. costocervical trunk supreme intercostal a. 14

next previous 2.2 the internal thoracic and anterior intercostal veins there may be one or more internal thoracic veins accompanying each internal thoracic artery. the internal thoracic veins receive blood from the intercostal spaces via the anterior intercostal veins. the anterior intercostal veins form venous anastomoses with the posterior intercostal veins in the thoracic wall roughly along the midclavicular line. the internal thoracic veins drain superiorly into the brachiocephalic veins, which unite to form the superior vena cava. left brachiocephalic vein azygous vein hemiazygous vein accessory hemiazygous vein posterior intercostal vein anterior intercostal vein right superior intercostal vein right brachiocephalic vein left superior intercostal vein internal thoracic vein anterior perforating branches 15

next previous 2.2 summarizing the blood supply of “the container” to summarize, the anterior and posterior intercostal arteries arise from distinct arterial sources, the internal thoracic arteries and the thoracic aorta, respectively. they form an arterial anastomosis in the thoracic wall. the anterior and posterior intercostal veins drain into distinct venous networks, the internal thoracic veins and the azygous venous system, respectively. they form a venous anastomosis in the thoracic wall. why is there only an “intercostal nerve” and not distinct anterior and posterior nerves? 16

next previous 2.2 lymphatic drainage follows venous drainage lymph from the chest wall drains anteriorly into parasternal lymph nodes, and from there into the bronchomediastinal trunk. on the chest plate, 17 identify the location of tas k parasternal lymph nodes on either side of the sternum. the parasternal lymph nodes collect some lymph from the breast . moisten and cover the chest plate; once again, uncover the prosection of the posterior / superior mediastinum. on the prosection, identify the location of intercostal tas k lymph nodes on either side of the vertebral column. lymph from the chest wall drains posteriorly into intercostal lymph nodes and from there into the thoracic duct. the lymphatic drainage of the thoracic wall follows its venous drainage.

next previous 2.2 the vagus nerve i continue studying the specimen of the posterior / superior mediastinum. identify the right and left tas k vagus nerves and their recurrent laryngeal branches. the vagus nerves descend through the neck from the brainstem, and their recurrent branches turn back to ascend to, and innervate, the larynx. observe that the right tas k recurrent laryngeal nerve recurs around the right subclavian artery, while the left recurrent laryngeal nerve recurs around the arch of the aorta. the recurrent laryngeal nerves ascend to the larynx on either side of the trachea. 18

next previous 2.2 the vagus nerve ii contributing to the visceral plexuses of the thorax, along with sympathetic splanchnic nerves derived from the upper chain ganglia. cervical cardiac nerves left recurrent laryngeal n. left vagus n. right vagus n. ligamentum arteriosum sympathetic trunk esophageal plexus posterior pulmonary plexus anterior pulmonary plexus 19 observe the vagus nerves tas k you should be able to clearly identify the esophageal and pulmonary plexuses in the specimen provided.

next previous 2.2 progress check 20 since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify an internal thoracic (internal mammary) artery. what artery gives rise to the internal thoracic artery? identify an anterior intercostal artery. define the term arterial anastomosis and describe an arterial anastomosis in the chest wall. where is it located? identify an internal thoracic (internal mammary) vein. into what vein does the internal thoracic artery drain? identify an anterior intercostal vein. define the term venous anastomosis and describe a venous anastomosis in the chest wall. where is it located? what two groups of lymph nodes process lymph from the chest wall? into which lymphatic vessels does each empty? identify the right and left vagus nerves and their recurrent laryngeal branches. around what vessels do the recurrent laryngeal nerves recur? identify the pulmonary and esophageal plexuses. what nerve delivers parasympathetic fibres to these plexuses? what nerves deliver sympathetic fibres to these plexuses? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next exercise.

2.3 the lungs and diaphragm resources cadaver 1 next what you’ll need: exercise selection

2.3 objectives next previous describe the pleural cavity. identify the features of the lungs. describe the serous membranes, the pleura, associated with the lungs and pleural cavity. identify the diaphragm and describe its innervation by the phrenic nerves. describe the concept of referred pain and understand its clinical significance. 2

next previous 2.3 uncovering the cadaver open the body bag. tas k uncover only the portion of the cadaver you are working on, to prevent other parts from drying out. remove the damp cloths from the cadaver’s chest and place them inside the body bag, at the cadaver’s feet. reflect the skin flaps from the thorax and remove the chest plate, thus exposing the thoracic contents. 3

next previous 2.3 pleura feel the surface tas k of a lung; it is smooth and slick. it is covered by a serous membrane called the visceral pleura . feel the inner surface tas k of the chest plate, lateral to the sternum; it too, is smooth and slick, like the lung surface. the inner surface of the chest wall, like the outer surface of the lung, is covered by a serous membrane, which in this location is called the parietal pleura . 4

next previous 2.3 the pleural cavities slide your hand tas k between the lungs and the chest wall. your hand is in the pleural cavities, which contain the lungs. the left and right pleural cavities are separated by the mediastinum . in life, the pleural cavities are potential spaces, containing only a capillary layer of fluid, the pleural fluid. pleural fluid is produced by the pleura. it acts as a lubricant, allowing the lungs to move in a friction-free manner relative to the inner surface of the thoracic wall as we breathe and our lungs expand and contract. 5

next previous 2.3 resource management now that you have finished looking at it, tas k give the chest plate from your cadaver to the pair working on task 2.3. remind them to keep it moist and wrapped when they are not looking at it, and to return it to the correct cadaver when they are finished with it. you will next remove the lungs from the cadaver. 6

next previous 2.3 removal of the lungs 7 remove both lungs from the cadaver, tas k the roots of the lungs consist of the airways, blood vessels, lymphatics and nerves that service the organ, all bound together by connective tissue and surrounded by pleura. the root of the lung attaches it to the structures of the mediastinum. it is at the root of the lung that the parietal pleura is continuous with the visceral pleura. one at a time. start by isolating the root of the lung with your hands . gently pull the lung laterally, away from the mediastinum to create more room in which to work, and to ensure that you cut through the root of the lung and not the lung itself, laterally, nor the heart, medially. cut through the structures comprising the root of the lung using large, blunt scissors. ease each lung out of the pleural cavity. if it doesn’t come easily, use your fingers to check that you’ve cut through all of the structures in the root of the lung. you will next examine the lungs, and then the pleural cavities.

next previous 2.3 the features of the lungs identify the diaphragmatic surface of the lung, adjacent to the diaphragm. because the lungs are pyramidal in shape, they are described as having a base and 8 tas k identify the costal surface of the lung, tas k its extensive curved surface, adjacent to the ribs. identify the mediastinal surface of the lung, adjacent to the mediastinum. in the mediastinal surface, identify the hilum of the lung, the region where the airways, nerves, blood vessels and lymphatics that service the lung enter or leave the organ. these structures themselves, bound together by connective tissue, are the root of the lung. an apex . the diaphragmatic surface of the lung is also known as the base of the lung. identify the apex of the lung, opposite its base. the apex of the lung extends above the clavicle into the thoracic inlet. now that you have examined the lungs, set them out of the way for the time being, perhaps at the foot of the table, wrapped in a damp cloth to keep them from drying out.

next previous 2.3 the pleural cavity turn your attention to the pleural cavity. the walls of the pleural cavity, and the parietal pleura that line them, have names that correspond to the surfaces of the lungs. identify the surfaces of the parietal pleura: tas k costal mediastinal diaphragmatic cervical pleura lining the cupola of the pleural cavity, which houses the apex of the lung the parietal pleura is continuous with the visceral pleura at the root of the lung. to summarize, you should appreciate that the pleural cavity is a closed, potential space, containing only a capillary layer of serous fluid, secreted by the pleura. this structural arrangement allows the lungs to move in a friction-free manner relative to their container as they change size during the respiratory cycle. 9

next previous 2.3 clinical significance: pleural effusion excess fluid accumulates in the pleural space. as the fluid volume increases in the pleural cavity, lung volume decreases. in pleural effusion, info 10 lung function can be compromised, or the lung can collapse. fluid can be aspirated via a needle inserted through the intercostal space at the base of the lung and analyzed to determine the underlying cause of the pleural effusion. pleural effusion may result from infection, malignancy, cardiac failure, hepatic disease or pulmonary embolism. fluid accumulates in the lowest part of the chest in response to gravity. therefore, if a patient is standing upright when an x-ray is taken, the radio-opaque fluid will create a horizontal line below the lung, at the air-fluid interface.

next previous 2.3 attachments of the diaphragm turn your attention to the diaphragm. the diaphragm is a thin muscular sheet that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominopelvic cavity. the diaphragm originates from the inferior thoracic aperture, defined by the t12 vertebra, the 12th and 11th ribs, the costal margin and the xiphisternal joint. superior thoracic aperture sternal angle sternum diaphragm sternum right dome central tendon left dome esophageal hiatus aortic hiatus xiphoid process inferior thoracic aperture rib xi rib xii 11

next previous 2.3 the shape of the diaphragm run your hand around the peripheral attachment of the diaphragm tas k superior thoracic aperture sternal angle sternum diaphragm sternum right dome central tendon left dome esophageal hiatus aortic hiatus xiphoid process inferior thoracic aperture rib xi rib xii the fibres of the diaphragm are organized radially , and insert into its non-contractile central tendon. therefore, when the muscular fibres contract, the dome of the diaphragm flattens, and the volume of the thoracic cavity increases. to the inferior thoracic aperture. notice that the posterior attachment of the diaphragm to the t12 vertebra and ribs is significantly inferior to its anterior attachment to the xiphisternal joint, as illustrated on the right. 12 notice the domed shape of the diaphragm, and the direction of its muscle fibres.

next previous 2.3 structures pass through the diaphragm structures that must pass between the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavity must pass either through or behind the diaphragm. these structures include the thoracic / abdominal aorta, the esophagus and the inferior vena cava, amongst other nervous, lymphatic and vascular structures. you will not be able to see these structures passing through the diaphragm in your cadaver because these are mediastinal structures. you will dissect the mediastinum later in the year, during your cardiovascular block, and observe these relationships directly at that time. 13

next previous 2.3 the course of nerves within the thorax the diaphragm is composed of striated voluntary muscle, and is therefore innervated by the somatic nervous system, like any other structure composed of skeletal muscle. the diaphragm is innervated primarily by the phrenic nerves, somatic nerves that form from twigs arising from the ventral primary rami of the c3, c4 and c5 spinal nerves. the phrenic nerves descend in the neck and pass into the thorax via the thoracic inlet. they run along the lateral aspect of the mediastinum, deep to the mediastinal parietal pleura, and anterior to the root of the lung. the vagus nerves also descend in the neck and pass into the thorax via the thoracic inlet, but, in contrast to the phrenic nerves, the vagus nerves pass posterior to the root of the lung. c3 c4 c5 left phrenic nerve right phrenic nerve pericardial branch of phrenic nerve diaphragm pericardium 14

next previous 2.3 isolating the phrenic nerve look at the lateral aspect of the tas k mediastinum on both sides of your cadaver, keeping these anatomical relationships in mind, and find the phrenic nerves. stabilize the phrenic nerve with tas k large forceps or your fingers, and gently ease the phrenic nerves free from the lateral aspect of the mediastinum. observe their course to the dome of the diaphragm. leave the phrenic nerves intact along their length, attached to the dome of the diaphragm. esophagus left subclavian a. left vagus n. left recurrent laryngeal n. left pulmonary a. bronchus thoracic aorta diaphragm rib i left common carotid a. brachiocephalic plexus left brachiocephalic v. left phrenic n. ligamentum arteriosum pericardial sac diaphragm bronchus right vagus n. right phrenic n. svc left brachiocephalic v. right brachiocephalic v. brachiocephalic trunk trachea esophagus azygous v. esophageal plexus esophagus 15 you will be able to see them through the mediastinal parietal pleura; they will appear as thick white cords running anterior to the root of the lung. confirm your identification with your ta before proceeding.

next previous 2.3 innervation of the diaphragm because the diaphragm is striated muscle, it is controlled by somatic motor neurons, as are the skeletal muscles of the limbs and body wall. the cell bodies of these somatic motor neurons are located in the c3 - c5 segments of the spinal cord and their axons form the phrenic nerve. sensory fibres return from the diaphragm and its overlying pleura, as well as from the mediastinal parietal pleura and the pericardial sac, to the c3-c5 segments of the spinal cord. like any other somatic nerve, the phrenic nerve also contains sympathetic postganglionic fibres. these arise from cervical sympathetic chain ganglia, destined to control vascular smooth muscle within its territory. 16

next previous 2.3 clinical significance: referred pain along the phrenic nerve, due to irritation of: the diaphragm, its serous coverings, the mediastinal pleura, the pericardial sac, or the phrenic nerve itself somewhere along its course, will be conveyed back to the spinal cord at the c3-c5 levels. these levels of the spinal cord also receive sensory afferents from the c3 - c5 dermatome, which includes the skin overlying the shoulder. therefore pain arising from irritation of the diaphragm may be referred to the shoulder; i.e. the nervous system interprets pain from the diaphragm as originating from the skin overlying the shoulder. a physician must consider the diaphragm and phrenic nerve in investigating an unexplained complaint of shoulder pain. pain signals conveyed centrally info 17

next previous 2.3 proper care of the cadaver when you are finished your studies, thoroughly moisten the interior of the pleural cavities and the exterior of the lungs, and replace the lungs in the pleural cavities. cover them with a damp cloth. moisten the chest plate, replace it on the cadaver’s chest, and close the skin flaps. replace the layers of damp cloths that were on the cadaver’s chest when you uncovered it. be careful to cover all incisions, leaving no incision open to air. close the body bag. 18

next previous 2.3 progress check 19 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the parietal and visceral pleura. what is a serous membrane and what is its function? identify the pleural space. what is a potential space? what is pleural fluid? where is it found? where does it come from? what is its function? identify the surfaces of the lungs: costal, mediastinal and diaphragmatic. identify the apex and base of the lungs. identify the root of the lung. do not identify the individual structures within the roof of the lung. identify the surfaces of the pleural cavity: costal, mediastinal and diaphragmatic; identify the cupola of the pleural cavity. what occupies the cupola in life? where are the parietal and visceral pleura continuous with one another? what is pleural effusion? what is an air-fluid interface? what are two complications of pleural effusion? what are the attachments of the diaphragm? how does its shape change with contraction? describe the relationships of the phrenic and vagus nerves to the roots of the lungs. identify the phrenic nerves. from what spinal level do the phrenic nerves arise? what types of nerve fibres do the phrenic nerves contain? name three structures that receive sensory innervation from the phrenic nerve. why does pain from these structures refer to the shoulder? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next exercise.

2.4 mediastinal subdivisions, the heart in situ and the pericardial cavity resources cadaver 2 next what you’ll need: exercise selection

2.4 objectives next previous describe the subdivisions of the mediastinum. identify the features of the anterior mediastinum. identify the fibrous and serous pericardium of the pericardial sac and describe the extent of the pericardial cavity. identify the surfaces of the heart. describe the orientation of the heart in situ. 2

next previous 2.4 the subdivisions of the mediastinum i the mediastinum is the region between the lungs. it extends from the superior thoracic aperture to the inferior thoracic aperture (see section 2.2 for a description of these bony landmarks), and from the sternum, anteriorly, to the thoracic vertebrae, posteriorly. for the purpose of organizing our understanding of its contents, it is separated into four subdivisions. the superior mediastinum extends from the superior thoracic aperture to a horizontal plane passing through the sternal angle and the intervertebral disc between the t4 and t5 vertebrae. below this plane, it is further subdivided into the anterior, middle and posterior mediastinum. 3

next previous 2.4 the subdivisions of the mediastinum ii the middle mediastinum consists of the pericardial sac and its contents, the heart in the pericardial cavity. the anterior mediastinum, therefore, is the region between the sternum and the pericardial sac. the posterior mediastinum is the region between the pericardial sac and the t5 - t12 thoracic vertebrae. in this section of the lab, you will be introduced to the anterior and middle mediastinum. 4

next previous 2.4 the anterior mediastinum open the body bag. tas k uncover only the portion of the cadaver you are working on, to prevent other parts from drying out. remove the damp cloths from the cadaver’s chest and place them inside the body bag, at identify the sternum, tas k which is the anterior limit of the anterior mediastinum; and the internal thoracic arteries and veins, running parallel to the lateral border of the sternum. the internal thoracic arteries and veins supply the anterior chest wall. you may also notice parasternal lymph nodes lying along the internal thoracic vessels. this collection of nodes receives lymph from the anterior chest wall, including from some breast tissue (the majority of the lymph derived from breast tissue drains into the axillary nodes). 5 the foot of the cadaver. reflect the skin flaps from the thorax, remove the chest plate and look at its internal surface.

next previous 2.4 resource management now that you have finished looking at it, give the chest plate from your cadaver to the pair working on task 2.3. remind them to keep it moist and wrapped when they are not looking at it, and to return it to the correct cadaver when they are finished with it. 6

next previous 2.4 the thymus gland is located within the anterior mediastinum turn your attention to the cadaver. at this point you should see a collection of adipose tissue in the midline, anterior to the heart, and the lungs on either side. while the bulk of the thymus gland is located in the superior mediastinum, posterior to the manubrium of the sternum, it may extend inferiorly into the anterior mediastinum. the thymus gland is involved in the development of the immune system, particularly in children and adolescents. it is during these early life years that it is largest in size. in the elderly, it is atrophied and often indistinguishable from adjacent adipose tissue. know the location of the thymus gland, but do not try to identify the thymus gland in your cadaver. adipose tissue left internal thoracic a. tiv/v vertebral level pericardial sac thymus right internal thoracic a. 7

next previous 2.4 the fibrous pericardium using blunt dissection (no scalpels!) tas k with large forceps and large, blunt closed scissors (ask your ta to demonstrate), scrape away adipose tissue to thoroughly clean the anterior surface of the fibrous pericardium. the fibrous pericardium defines the middle mediastinum. it is composed of dense, irregular connective tissue, and as such, is a tough, white, inextensible sack. 8

next previous 2.4 opening the fibrous pericardium open the fibrous pericardium following these dissection steps: tas k using forceps, lift the fibrous pericardium away from the heart, and only now may you open your scissors. gently pierce the fibrous pericardium in the midline with the sharp point of the scissors. do not insert your instrument deeply through the sack; you are trying to avoid impaling the heart. cut a vertical slit along the midline of the fibrous pericardium. make two horizontal slits, one at the top of the sack, the other at the bottom of the sack. you are now able to reflect the fibrous pericardium away from the heart, like opening two doors. 9

next previous 2.4 the pericardial cavity i examine the inner surface tas k of the pericardial sac. it is smooth and slippery, unlike the outer surface of the pericardial sac. this is because the pericardial sac is composed of two fused layers, an outer fibrous layer and an inner serous layer (see section 2.4 for a description of serous membranes). the serous membrane lining the inner surface of the fibrous pericardium is the parietal portion of the serous pericardium (analogous to the parietal pleura). touch the surface of the heart. tas k the heart is covered by the same serous membrane, but here it is called the visceral portion of the serous pericardium (analogous to the visceral pleura). 10

next previous 2.4 the pericardial cavity ii slide your hand into the pericardial sac tas k and explore the extent of the pericardial space. note that this space is a dead end and that the visceral pericardium lining the outside of the heart reflects onto the inner surface of the pericardial sac to become the parietal pericardium. thus, the parietal and visceral serous pericardia are continuous at the base of the great vessels. here, the fibrous pericardium becomes continuous with the outermost connective tissue layer of the great vessels, the tunica adventitia. the pericardial space is a potential space containing only a capillary layer of serous fluid, the pericardial fluid. pericardial fluid is secreted by the parietal and visceral pericardia. it acts as a lubricant permitting the heart to move in a friction-free manner within the pericardial sac. next you will study the shape and position of the heart in the thorax. 11

next previous 2.4 anatomical position of the heart in situ i like the lungs, the heart is pyramidal in shape, and therefore, it is also described as having an apex and a base . the orientation of the heart in the thorax can be visualized by imagining that this pyramid has been tipped forward, and is thus resting on one of its sides. the apex of the heart is pointed downward, forward and to the left, and its base, being opposite its apex, is posterior. the pyramid rests on its diaphragmatic surface, its anterior surface faces the sternum, and it has a right and a left pulmonary surface. third costal cartilage sixth costal cartilage second intercostal space fifth intercostal space midclavicular line 12

next previous 2.4 anatomical position of the heart in situ ii it is also helpful to further imagine that the heart has been rotated to the left, and because of this, the right side of the heart is turned toward the front of the body. look at the heart in the thorax; tas k its anterior surface is facing you. note that its anterior surface is made up largely of the right ventricle. palpate the following: right atrium right ventricle right ventricle right atrium left atrium left ventricle left ventricle 13 the right pulmonary surface; it is made up largely of the right atrium. the left pulmonary surface; it is made up largely of the left ventricle. the diaphragmatic surface, by sliding your hand inferior to the heart. it is made up largely of the left ventricle, with a smaller contribution from the right ventricle.

next previous 2.4 anatomical position of the heart in situ iii in a chest x-ray, the heart is described as having a right border, a left border and an inferior border. what heart chamber forms the right border of the heart?_______________________ what heart chamber forms the left border of the heart? ________________________ what heart chamber forms the inferior border of the heart? _____________________ compare the position tas k of the heart in the thorax of the cadaver with a plain film chest x-ray, posteroanterior view (right). 14

next previous 2.4 caring for the cadaver when you are finished your studies, thoroughly moisten the cadaver’s heart, and close the pericardial sac. moisten the lungs and pleural cavities. cover the thoracic contents with a damp cloth. moisten the chest plate, replace it on the cadaver’s chest, and close the skin flaps. replace the layers of damp cloths that were on the cadaver’s chest when you uncovered it, being careful to cover all incisions, leaving no incision open to air. close the body bag. 15

next previous 2.4 progress check 16 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: what are the four subdivisions of the mediastinum? what are the borders between each? identify the internal thoracic arteries and veins, and any parasternal lymph nodes encountered. from what body region do the parasternal lymph nodes collect lymph? in which subdivision of the mediastinum is the thymus gland primarily located? into what other subdivision of the mediastinum might the thymus gland extend? identify the fibrous pericardium. of what tissue is the fibrous pericardium composed? what characteristic does this composition impose on the fibrous pericardium? what tissue lines the inner surface of the fibrous pericardium and what is the name of this layer? identify it. what tissue lines the outer surface of the heart, and what is the name of this layer? identify it. identify the pericardial space. what does it contain during life? where does this substance come from and what is its function? identify the apex and the base of the heart, its anterior, right pulmonary, left pulmonary and diaphragmatic surfaces. what heart chamber primarily makes up each of these surfaces? identify the borders of the heart in an x-ray, and state what chamber primarily makes up each. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next exercise.
